title: Specialized Diverge vs Crux: The best Specialized gravel bike in 2024
content:
Cyclist
Specialized Diverge vs Crux: The best Specialized gravel bike in 2024

The Specialized Diverge has been the gravel bike in the brand’s line-up since 2014, when the gravel category was in its infancy. It’s gone through a series of iterations since, gradually gaining in off-road competency, so that the current bike is a fully fledged modern gravel bike with the requisite wide tyre clearance, mounting points and go-anywhere gearing. 

That evolution went through a step change in 2023 with the introduction of the Diverge STR though. This bike adds rear Future Shock suspension to the standard Diverge’s front Future Shock, for a fully suspended bike with 30mm of rear and 20mm of front travel. 

At the same time, the Crux, another long-time Specialized model, has morphed from a cyclocross race bike to a lightweight gravel racer – very light in the case of the S-Works model. It’s pared-back relative to the Diverge, without extra mounts or comfort features, but offers the same 47mm tyre clearance.

So if you’re considering Specialized’s bikes for your next gravel bike, which should you choose? 

Here, we’ll compare the key features of Specialized’s gravel bikes and how the specs vary as you go down the ranges. We’ll then run through the whole Diverge STR, Diverge and Crux bike ranges and finally suggest some key pointers to help you to choose the best Specialized gravel bike for you.

Specialized Diverge vs Crux: Key features at a glance

Specialized Diverge STR

  • Front and rear Future Shock suspension with 20mm and 30mm travel
  • 1,400g claimed frame weight including rear damper 
  • Downtube storage compartment and full set of bag mounts
  • 47mm tyre clearance, 650b compatible

Specialized Diverge 

  • Front Future Shock suspension on all but the Diverge E5
  • 1,100g claimed frame weight (carbon)
  • Downtube storage on most carbon frames 
  • 47mm tyre clearance, 650b compatible

Specialized Crux

  • No added suspension
  • No frame storage
  • No mounting points
  • Claimed frame weight of 725g for S-Works and 825g for FACT 10r carbon frames
  • Claimed frame weight of 1,399g for DSW alloy frame
  • 47mm tyre clearance, 650b compatible

Specialized Diverge vs Crux: suspension

Unlike the Crux, the Diverge STR and all except the base model Diverge offer suspension, front only in the standard Diverge and both front and rear in the Diverge STR.

Diverge and Diverge STR suspension options

The Diverge’s range of suspension systems fitted across the different specs is pretty confusing, so we’ve set out the different front and rear Future Shock suspension options for the whole Diverge range in this table, then explained what each does and doesn’t do.

Diverge specFront Future
Shock model		DampedAdjustable
when riding		TuneableRear Future
Shock
S-Works STR3.3YYYY
STR Pro3.3YYYY
STR Expert3.2YNYY
STR Comp3.2YNYY
Comp Carbon2YYNN
Sport Carbon1.5NNYN
Comp E51.5NNYN
E5NNNNN

Diverge front suspension

Front suspension comes from Specialized’s Future Shock system. There are various grades of front Future Shock represented across the Diverge range, all offering 20mm of travel at the handlebars and featuring hydraulic damping. Future Shock has gone through three generations and all three are represented in the different specs of the Diverge.

The latest Future Shock 3.0 system (of which there are multiple grades) has improved sealing over previous generations for better weatherproofing and improved serviceability. It allows you to swap out the spring if you want a softer or firmer ride. You can also add or remove preload spacers to tune the travel to the way you ride. All bikes with Future Shock 3.0 are sold with the springs and spacers needed to change suspension characteristics.

The Future Shock 3.3 fitted to the Diverge STR S-Works and Pro models is the most sophisticated. It allows on-the-go adjustment via a dial on the headtube top cap. It’s the same system as found in higher specs of the Specialized Roubaix SL8.

The Diverge STR Expert and Comp include Future Shock 3.2 front suspension. Although this isn’t adjustable when riding, it’s still hydraulically damped and tuneable.

The (non-STR) Diverge Comp Carbon incorporates the previous generation Future Shock 2.0. This has less robust weatherproofing and a single spring rate, so it’s not tunable. Rather than allowing you to vary the damping as you ride, the top cap dial acts as a lockout and is on or off. 

There’s a further swap-out with the Diverge Sport Carbon and Diverge Comp E5, which include Future Shock 1.5 and don’t have an adjustment dial or a lockout.

It’s only the base model Diverge E5 which has a fully rigid fork assembly.

All grades of front Future Shock can be upgraded to the latest 3.0 system.

Diverge STR rear suspension

The Diverge STR models incorporate rear Future Shock as well as front Future Shock. 

Rear Future Shock provides 30mm of travel at the saddle, with the fore and aft movement of the seatpost controlled by a damper housed in the top tube. You can adjust the amount of damping as you ride and also tune its rebound off-bike.

The Diverge STR is supplied with two different stiffnesses of frame post (which houses the seatpost proper) and each can be mounted in two positions, allowing fine-tuning of the ride characteristics. 

The system has built-in sag when there’s a rider aboard, but preserves a constant distance from the saddle to the bottom bracket, for optimum pedalling despite the suspension. Stand on the pedals and there’s no rear-end bounce either.

Crux suspension

The Crux range is easier: none of the bikes are equipped with active suspension, relying on the tyres to smooth the ride. Although the frame provides clearance for 47mm tyres, Specialized fits 38mm wide tyres to all specs, offering plenty of mud clearance, although too wide for use in officially sanctioned cyclocross races.

Specialized Diverge vs Crux: geometry

 Diverge STRDivergeCrux
Frame size565656
Seat tube length500500546
Seat tube angle74°73.5°73.5°
Head tube length130133147
Head tube angle71.75°71.75°72°
Effective top tube length570573568
Bottom bracket drop858072
Chainstay length429425425
Frame reach392392397
Frame stack609610578
Wheelbase104410421033
Trail576164
Front centre629630618

All measurements in millimetres unless indicated

A major difference between the Crux and the Diverge family is in their geometry, which reflects the difference between the Crux’s gravel racing focus and the Diverge’s wider-ranging objectives. Above, we’ve taken the size 56 bikes as an example.

The Crux has a lower stack and slightly longer frame reach than the Diverge, so riders are going to be in a longer and lower ride position, which along with less bottom bracket drop should give a more racy ride. The wheelbase is shorter too, thanks to a shorter front centre measurement than the Diverge. There’s a longer seat tube, so there will be less free seatpost length.

Turning to the Diverge, the standard bike and the STR are similar in geometry. There’s a more upright seat tube in the STR, reflecting the sag to the bike’s rear suspension once a rider is aboard. 

Specialized says that the small differences between the Diverge and the Diverge STR are due to the STR’s rear suspension layout. The relatively low trail figure suggests that the Diverge’s steering should be a little faster than the Crux though. 

Specialized Diverge vs Crux: frame grades and weights

There’s a wide array of different frames on offer across the Diverge and Crux, everything from premium carbon fibre, usually the preserve of top spec road bikes, to E5 alloy.

The S-Works Crux gets the cream of the carbon, with FACT 12r, also seen in the S-Works Tarmac SL8, Specialized’s pro-level road race bike, and the Aethos lightweight road bike. 

In fact, the S-Works Crux has much in common with the Aethos, with similar tube profiles and carbon lay-up, just adapted for gravel riding. This leads to a 725g claimed frame weight, which Specialized says makes the bike the lightest gravel bike you can buy.

The rest of the Crux carbon range swaps to FACT 10r carbon, although the 825g claimed frame weight is still low. 

The Crux DSW is claimed to be the lightest alloy gravel bike frameset in the world, with an unpainted frameset said to weigh 1,399g. 

It uses Specialized’s d’Alusio Smartweld tech, a patented process which Specialized says reduces tolerances in the joints, so that less welding material is needed. The Crux DSW frameset also has a single-piece downtube and bottom bracket shell, again lowering weight and improving frame strength.

All the Crux range now uses the SRAM UDH rear derailleur hanger standard, which Specialized says has been coupled to a further weight decrease.

All specs of the Diverge STR use the same frameset, made with FACT 11r carbon. Specialized claims a frame weight of 1,400g, including the rear suspension system.

Further down the range, the (non-STR) Diverge Comp Carbon is made of FACT 9r carbon, with a claimed 1,100g frame weight. 

The Diverge Sport Carbon is made of FACT 8r, while the Comp E5 and the E5 base model both use Specialized’s E5 alloy. The proliferation of different carbon grades and materials don’t have a huge effect on the complete bikes’ weights however.

Specialized Diverge vs Crux: groupsets

Almost all Specialized’s gravel bikes are 1x, although there’s a 2x option for the Diverge.

Both the Diverge and Crux ranges offer a choice of SRAM or Shimano groupsets. The S-Works Crux includes the 13-speed Full Mount SRAM Red XPLR groupset with a power meter.

Further down the Crux range, there are SRAM Force, Rival and Apex XPLR 1x options, as well as a Shimano GRX 1×12-speed bike.

The Diverge is heavily specced with 12-speed SRAM mullet builds, providing gear range of up to 10-50t. Diverge STR bikes include a Shimano GRX 1×12-speed option, while the standard Diverge has the Shimano GRX 2×12-speed Sport in its range, as well as SRAM Apex 1×11-speed on the Comp E5 and Shimano Claris 2×8-speed on the base model Diverge E5.

Specialized Diverge vs Crux: sizing

The Crux is available in frame sizes 49, 52, 54, 56, 58 and 61, accommodating rider heights from 155cm to 198cm. 

More sizes are on offer for some specs of the Diverge, with a size 44 and 64 added at either end of the range, which Specialized says should cater for riders from 142cm to 205cm tall.

Specialized Diverge vs Crux: wheels and tyres

There’s a progressive downspec of the wheels fitted to Specialized’s gravel bike ranges as you descend through the specs. 

Both the Diverge and Crux go through the same range of options, starting off with the top spec carbon Roval Terra CLX II and going via the Terra CL and C models before Specialized offers DT Swiss G540 alloy rims on its own hubs or its own-brand Axis wheelsets on lower specs.

The Roval Terra wheel range has a 25mm internal width carbon rim with hooked beads, while the DT G540 rims are 24mm wide, so both offer good support for wider gravel tyres. 

Specialized specs quite narrow (by current gravel bike standards) 42mm tyres on the Diverge and 38mm tyres on the Crux, although the wider rims should add a couple of millimetres to this stated width.

There’s plenty of scope to go wider though, with the Diverge STR, Diverge and Crux frames all offering 47mm clearance.

Specialized Diverge vs Crux: ranges compared

Next, we’ll run through the entire ranges for each of Specialized’s gravel bikes, from the most expensive to the entry spec for each, with a brief spec run-down including frame grade, groupset and wheelset, along with Specialized’s claimed weight for a size 56 bike. 

Specialized Diverge and Diverge STR bike range

S-Works Diverge STR

  • Frame: Diverge FACT 11r with front and rear Future Shock
  • Fork: FACT carbon with Future Shock 3.3
  • Handlebars: Roval Terra carbon
  • Groupset: SRAM Red/Eagle XX1 AXS 40t, 10-50t 12-speed
  • Wheels:  Roval Terra CLX II carbon
  • Saddle: S-Works Power with Mirror
  • Claimed weight: 8.88kg, size 56
  • Price: £12,000

Diverge STR Pro

  • Frame: Diverge FACT 11r with front and rear Future Shock
  • Fork: FACT carbon with Future Shock 3.3
  • Handlebars: Roval Terra carbon
  • Groupset: SRAM Force/Eagle X01 AXS 40t, 10-50t 12-speed
  • Wheels:  Roval Terra CL carbon
  • Saddle: S-Works Power with Mirror
  • Claimed weight: 9.18kg, size 56
  • Price: £8,000

  • Frame: Diverge FACT 11r with front and rear Future Shock
  • Fork: FACT carbon with Future Shock 3.2
  • Handlebars: Specialized Adventure Gear Hover alloy
  • Groupset: SRAM Rival/GX Eagle AXS 40t, 11-50t 12-speed 
  • Wheels:  Roval Terra C carbon
  • Saddle: BG Power Expert
  • Claimed weight: 9.93kg, size 56
  • Price: £6,250

Diverge STR Comp

  • Fork: FACT carbon with Future Shock 3.2
  • Handlebars: Specialized Adventure Gear Hover alloy
  • Groupset: Shimano GRX RX822-SGS 40t, 10-51t 12-speed
  • Wheels:  DT Swiss G540 rim on Specialized hubs
  • Saddle: BG Power Sport

  • Price: £4,500

Diverge Comp Carbon

  • Frame: Diverge FACT 9r with front Future Shock
  • Fork: FACT carbon with Future Shock 2.0
  • Handlebars: Specialized Adventure Gear Hover alloy
  • Groupset: SRAM Apex/X1 Eagle AXS 40t, 11-50t 12-speed
  • Wheels:  DT Swiss G540 rim on Specialized hubs
  • Saddle: BG Power Sport
  • Claimed weight: 9.98kg, size 56
  • Price: £4,000

Diverge Sport Carbon

  • Frame: Diverge FACT 8r with front and rear Future Shock
  • Fork: FACT carbon with Future Shock 1.5
  • Handlebars: Specialized Adventure Gear Hover alloy
  • Groupset: Shimano GRX RX820/RX610 46/30t, 11-36t 12-speed
  • Wheels:  DT Swiss G540 rim on Specialized hubs
  • Saddle: BG Power Sport
  • Claimed weight: 10.05kg, size 56
  • Price: £3,200

Diverge Comp E5

  • Frame: Diverge E5 alloy with front Future Shock
  • Fork: FACT carbon with Future Shock 1.5
  • Handlebars: Specialized Adventure Gear Hover alloy
  • Groupset: SRAM Apex 1, 40t, 11-42t 11-speed
  • Wheels:  Axis Elite Disc
  • Saddle: BG Power Sport
  • Claimed weight: 9.94kg, size 56
  • Price: £2,500

Diverge E5

  • Frame: Diverge E5 alloy 
  • Fork: FACT carbon
  • Handlebars: Specialized Shallow Drop alloy
  • Groupset: Shimano Claris, 50/34t, 11-34t 8-speed
  • Wheels:  Axis Elite Disc
  • Saddle: BG Bridge
  • Claimed weight: 10.24kg, size 56
  • Price: £1,200

Specialized S-Works Diverge STR frameset

You can, in addition, buy the top spec S-Works Diverge STR frameset and build your bike yourself. The size 56 frameset has a 2.98kg claimed weight, including fork, seatpost, bearings and suspension, with the price of £4,750 reflecting the frame’s sophisticated engineering.

Specialized Crux bike range

S-Works Crux

  • Frame: S-Works Crux FACT 12r
  • Fork: S-Works FACT carbon
  • Handlebars: Roval Terra carbon 
  • Groupset: SRAM Red XPLR 40t, 10-46t 13-speed with power meter
  • Wheels:  Roval Terra CLX II
  • Saddle: S-Works Power with Mirror
  • Claimed weight: 6.94kg, size 56
  • Price: £11,500

Specialized Crux Pro

  • Fork: S-Works FACT carbon
  • Handlebars:  Roval Terra carbon
  • Groupset: SRAM Force XPLR AXS 40t, 10-44t 12-speed
  • Wheels:  Roval Terra CL
  • Saddle:  Power Pro with Mirror
  • Claimed weight: 7.63kg, size 56
  • Price: Coming soon

Specialized Crux Expert

  • Fork: S-Works FACT carbon
  • Handlebars:  Specialized Adventure Gear alloy
  • Groupset: SRAM Rival XPLR AXS 40t, 10-44t 12-speed
  • Wheels:  Roval Terra C
  • Saddle: BG Power Expert
  • Claimed weight: 8.07kg, size 56
  • Price: £5,500

  • Frame: Crux FACT 10r
  • Fork: S-Works FACT carbon
  • Handlebars:  Specialized Adventure Gear alloy
  • Groupset: Shimano GRX RX820-GS 40t, 10-45t 12-speed
  • Wheels:  DT Swiss G540 rim on Specialized hubs
  • Saddle: BG Power Sport

  • Price: £3,500

Specialized Crux DSW Comp

  • Frame: Specialized E5 alloy
  • Fork: S-Works FACT carbon
  • Handlebars:  Specialized Adventure Gear alloy
  • Groupset: SRAM Apex XPLR mechanical 40t, 11-44t 12-speed
  • Wheels:  DT Swiss G540 rim on Specialized hubs
  • Saddle: BG Power Sport
  • Claimed weight: 8.53kg, size 56
  • Price: £2,300

Crux frameset

Specialized sells the Crux as two different framesets. The carbon S-Works Crux frameset has a claimed weight of 1.43kg including the fork and seatpost and a price tag of £4,500. 

There’s also the alloy Crux DSW frameset on offer. This has a 1.98kg claimed weight and a more reasonable £1,500 sticker price.

Specialized Diverge vs Crux: which should you choose?

Although this looks like a binary choice, the two different Diverge framesets make it a three-way decision. So first, you need to decide whether you want suspension and more all-round capability, or if you’re content to let the tyres do the work and handle the bumps yourself. 

If so, the Crux range provides a simpler, cheaper solution which saves you over a kilogram in weight across the range at comparable price levels to the equivalent Diverge models. It’s a more racy bike with edgier handling though.

You can potentially add significantly to the Crux’s ride-smoothing with a swap-out from the narrowish (for a gravel bike) 38mm tyres to something closer to the frame’s 47mm clearance, although at the expense of space for mud build-up.

If you do want suspension, you’re going to have to decide between just front-end or full suspension. The latter comes with a hefty price tag, but does deliver a super-capable gravel bike, able to add a dose of comfort to the roughest gravel rides. 

The alloy bikes provide a more affordable entry point into both the Crux and Diverge bike ranges.

If your gravel riding is more about exploring trickier terrain and multi-day rides, then the Diverge is likely to be for you. The Crux is geared more towards fast gravel riding, gravel racing and cyclocross use and lacks the mounting points that a gravel adventurer might prefer.

Now you’ve got through all that, you might be ready to buy one from specialized.com.

Read our full reviews of the Specialized Diverge, Diverge STR and Crux for more details to help you to choose.
